wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup 6/5/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

12 Ways to Increase Employee Engagement

The author argues that the top three drivers of engagement are: 1) An employee’s relationship with his supervisor, 2) His belief in senior leadership, and 3) His pride in working for the company. Through a guided list of 12 true or false questions, the article elucidates readers on identifying target areas in which their companies are lacking. As a result, companies can dedicate more resources and effort to these employee engagement areas to drive positive change.

Walking the Walk

Firms today are increasingly supporting sustainability initiatives because it is more profitable for them in the long run: with the price of renewable energy and sustainable supply chain sourcing dropping, businesses can cut emissions and waste by high percentages while simultaneously boosting profits. These firms might not be profitable because they are being green, however, but because they are better run, as greenness can denote better management. As one executive states, Our motives are not exactly altruistic…Our clients and stakeholders demand such initiatives.

Global Employee Engagement Levels Have Plateaued, and Average Employee’s Perception of the Work Experience is Deteriorating

A new global survey from Aon Hewitt has shown that although overall employee engagement has risen one percentage point to 62% from the previous year, employees’ overall satisfaction with work has dropped 28%. How could such a sharp contrast arise? The study suggests that the root cause could be a mismatch between employee engagement levels and employee value and empowerment levels. Thus, it is all the more important to promote a culture of engagement and collaboration throughout the hierarchy of the workplace.

CIPD: Employees want a family feel’ at the heart of company culture

The latest Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) report states that of those that work in a formalized and structured organization, the vast majority wishes to work in an org with a family feel and collaborative culture. This finding stems from employees at companies of all sizes. Therefore, CIPD recommends that organizations should periodically check in to see if there is a mismatch between type of culture employees aspire to work in and the one currently present. Equipped with this information, managers can drive a corporate culture overhaul if need be.

Why B Corps Have Great Employee Engagement

In addition to being frontrunners in the sustainable businesses arena, B corporations are finding other examples of how their certification has been beneficial: B corps have recorded higher levels of employee engagement and retention, especially among the millennial generation (those under 30). Because these businesses imbue passion for sustainability and serving the greater good into their daily routines, they are able to attract top talent looking to promote both social and financial goals in the workplace. In turn, these employees at B corps are able to connect with the higher purpose of their companies and drive bottom line performance.
